turns.speaker: MANZANO
turns.text: [Is it true? Creasy saved the little girl that was kidnapped yesterday.]

turns.speaker: ROSANNA
turns.text: [And left three more dead men.]

turns.speaker: MANZANO
turns.text: [When you talked to him, did he look sane?]

turns.speaker: ROSANNA
turns.text: [No. Not by the rules of polite society at least.]

turns.speaker: MANZANO
turns.text: [I think he's... magnificent.]

turns.speaker: MANZANO
turns.text: [You only fuck me to get information.]

turns.speaker: ROSANNA
turns.text: [You only give information so you can fuck me.]

turns.speaker: MANZANO
turns.text: [A beautiful circle.]

turns.speaker: ROSANNA
turns.text: [And as long as we're talking information, there's something else as well.]

turns.speaker: MANZANO
turns.text: [I should start going for your tits first.]

turns.speaker: ROSANNA
turns.text: [Who's that?]

turns.speaker: MANZANO
turns.text: [He's the man, 'the Boss?' My guys got into the house on the pretext of giving cholera shots. We had to inject the whole Barrio. We bugged the house and stole the picture of him.]

turns.speaker: RAYBURN
turns.text: He's not a cop killer.

turns.speaker: MANZANO
turns.text: I'm sure he isn't. Though he's certainly adept at killing.

turns.speaker: RAYBURN
turns.text: He was doing his job, protecting the girl. If police were involved, you figure it out. I'm here for him.

turns.speaker: MANZANO
turns.text: So am I.

turns.speaker: MANZANO
turns.text: Pollo Pibil. Chicken and chorizo sausage. Hmmmh. They marinate it in lemon and orange juice. It's a stew really.

turns.speaker: RAYBURN
turns.text: I already ate.

turns.speaker: MANZANO
turns.text: Tell me about your friend Creasy.

turns.speaker: RAYBURN
turns.text: You just said it. He's my friend. Nothing else to say.

turns.speaker: MANZANO
turns.text: I read the file. You and Creasy have been seen quite a bit together.

turns.speaker: RAYBURN
turns.text: Two tourists who never went home.

turns.speaker: MANZANO
turns.text: You helped him get this job.

turns.speaker: RAYBURN
turns.text: That's what friends do.

turns.speaker: MANZANO
turns.text: Yes. But if I traced Creasy to you, others will do it as well. Their facilities are as good as my own, if not better.

turns.speaker: RAYBURN
turns.text: I can take care of myself.

turns.speaker: MANZANO
turns.text: You and Creasy both. A two man army according to Interpol. Panama. Lebanon with the Druze. Desert Storm. Where you were contracted by the U.S. Army to hunt down elite Iraqi military commanders.  You two were a married couple.

turns.speaker: RAYBURN
turns.text: The kind that gets divorced, but still stay friends.

turns.speaker: MANZANO
turns.text: What happened to him? What happened to Creasy?

turns.speaker: RAYBURN
turns.text: None of your business. Or mine for that matter. I got nothing more to say.

turns.speaker: MANZANO
turns.text: This is my jurisdiction. I want these men as much as Creasy does.

turns.speaker: RAYBURN
turns.text: He'll deliver more justice in a weekend, than ten years of your courts and tribunals. So stay out of his way.

turns.speaker: MANZANO
turns.text: I plan to. I'll even help him if I can. He's going to lead me to the 'The Dreamer'. Someone I want very badly. But I'd like to understand him. Give me that.

turns.speaker: RAYBURN
turns.text: Pinta Martin Ramos is just a number to you. Tragic, a public outcry, but a number. One more dead.

turns.speaker: MANZANO
turns.text: What was she to Creasy then?

turns.speaker: RAYBURN
turns.text: Light. At the end of a long, dark tunnel. Somehow, she showed him it was alright to live again.

turns.speaker: MANZANO
turns.text: And they took that away.

turns.speaker: RAYBURN
turns.text: A man can be an artist in anything. Stone, paint, words. Food. Anything if his soul is true to it. Creasy's art is death. And he's about to paint his masterpiece.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: I told you she wasn't especially attractive, but that she had a good deal of charm, and she's really a real nice girl...

turns.speaker: DR. KEEGAN
turns.text: She's all right, Andy. It's just that I get one Saturday night off every three weeks, and I was expecting something better, that's all.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: I told you she wasn't attractive...

turns.speaker: DR. KEEGAN
turns.text: You told me that she was a little tall, but that she wasn't bad looking at all.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Millie's been after me to fix her up with a date, so I...

turns.speaker: DR. KEEGAN
turns.text: All right, I'm having a fair time. It's just that I get one Saturday night off in three weeks, and I wanted to wind up with something tonight.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Hey, Herbie...

turns.speaker: DR. KEEGAN
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: You wanna have a drink before we start dancing?

turns.speaker: DR. KEEGAN
turns.text: Listen. You people go grab a table. I'll be back inna minute. I'll be right back.

turns.speaker: ANGIE
turns.text: So waddaya feel like doing tonight?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I don't know, Ang'. Wadda you feel like doing?

turns.speaker: ANGIE
turns.text: Well, we oughta do something. It's Saturday night. I don't wanna go bowling like last Saturday. How about calling up that big girl we picked up inna movies about a month ago in the RKO Chester?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Which one was that?

turns.speaker: ANGIE
turns.text: That big girl that was sitting in front of us with the skinny friend.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Oh, yeah.

turns.speaker: ANGIE
turns.text: We took them home alla way out in Brooklyn. Her name was Mary Feeney. What do you say? You think I oughta give her a ring? I'll take the skinny one.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: She probably got a date by now, Angie.

turns.speaker: ANGIE
turns.text: Well, let's call her up. What can we lose?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I didn't like her, Angie. I don't feel like calling her up.

turns.speaker: ANGIE
turns.text: Well, what do you feel like doing tonight?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I don't know. What do you feel like doing?

turns.speaker: ANGIE
turns.text: Well, we're back to that, huh? I say to you, "What do you feel like doing tonight?" And you say to me, "I don't know, what do you feel like doing?" And then we wind up sitting around your house with a coupla cansa beer, watching Sid Caesar on television. Well, I tell you what I feel like doing. I feel like calling up this Mary Feeney. She likes you.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: What makes you say that?

turns.speaker: ANGIE
turns.text: I could see she likes you.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Yeah, sure.

turns.speaker: ANGIE
turns.text: I'll call her up.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: You call her up for yourself, Angie. I don't feel like calling her up.

turns.speaker: ANGIE
turns.text: Boy, you're getting to be a real drag, you know that?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Angie, I'm thirty-four years old. I been looking for a girl every Saturday night of my life. I'm tired of looking. Everybody's always telling me to get married. Get married. Get married. Don't you think I wanna get married? I wanna get married. They drive me crazy. Now, I don't wanna wreck your Saturday night for you, Angie. You wanna go somewhere, you go ahead. I don't wanna go.

turns.speaker: ANGIE
turns.text: My old lady, every word outta her mouth, when you gonna get married?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: My mother, boy, she drives me crazy.

turns.speaker: ANGIE
turns.text: So what do you feel like doing tonight?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I don't know. What do you feel like doing?

turns.speaker: ANGIE
turns.text: Not a bad crowd tonight, you know?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: There was one nice-looking one there inna black dress and beads, but she's dancing now.

turns.speaker: ANGIE
turns.text: There's a nice-looking little short one for you right now.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Where?

turns.speaker: ANGIE
turns.text: Down there. That little one there.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Yeah, she looks all right from here.

turns.speaker: ANGIE
turns.text: Well, waddaya say, you wanna ask them? I'll take the one inna green dress.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I think this number is a little fast. Wait a minute.

turns.speaker: ANGIE
turns.text: Where you been, for Pete sakes?! I been looking all over for you.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I looked for you, Angie, before I cut out, but I couldn't find you.

turns.speaker: ANGIE
turns.text: I been looking all over for you!

turns.speaker: ANGIE
turns.text: Waddaya gonna do now?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I'm gonna take Clara home. It's close to one.

turns.speaker: ANGIE
turns.text: You want me to ride down with you?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: What for?

turns.speaker: ANGIE
turns.text: It's early.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: It must be one o'clock.

turns.speaker: ANGIE
turns.text: It's Saturday night! There's still plenty-a action around!

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Angie, by the time I get Clara home, it's gonna be one, one-thirty. By the time I get home, it's gonna be two o'clock. I gotta get up for ten o'clock mass tomorrow.

turns.speaker: ANGIE
turns.text: All right, I'll see you!

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Where you going?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: We gotta whole pot inna kitchen. We give you a plate-a your own.

turns.speaker: ANGIE
turns.text: Oh, I couldn't eat nothing. My mother just stuffed me right up to the jaws.

turns.speaker: ANGIE
turns.text: Who you gonna call?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I was gonna call that girl from last night. Take her to a movie tonight.

turns.speaker: ANGIE
turns.text: Are you kidding?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Listen, Angie, I wanna tell you, you were very impolite last night. I introduced you to the girl, you just turned and walked off. Now, why did you do that?

turns.speaker: ANGIE
turns.text: You got me mad, that's why. Hey, Joe, show Marty that picture.

turns.speaker: ANGIE
turns.text: Marty, let's go downna Seventy-Second Street area tonight.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I don't feel like going, Angie. I thought I'd take this girl to a movie.

turns.speaker: ANGIE
turns.text: Boy, you really musta made out good last night.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: We just talked.

turns.speaker: ANGIE
turns.text: Boy, she musta been some talker. She musta been about fifty years old.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I didn't think she was so bad-looking.

turns.speaker: ANGIE
turns.text: She musta kept you inna shadows all night.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I told this dog I was gonna call her today about two-thirty.

turns.speaker: ANGIE
turns.text: Brush her. Listen, you wanna come with me tonight, or you wanna go with this dog?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Waddaya getting so sore about?

turns.speaker: ANGIE
turns.text: I looked all over for you last night, you know that?

turns.speaker: BARTENDER
turns.text: Marty, your mother wants you onna phone.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Come on over about half past seven, we'll think of something.  Hello, Ma, what's the matter?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Hello, Lou, Angie come in yet?

turns.speaker: BARTENDER
turns.text: He was here last night till about two o'clock. I hear you really got stuck with a dog last night.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Who told you that?

turns.speaker: BARTENDER
turns.text: Angie. He says she was a real scrawny- looking thing.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: She wasn't so bad.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Hey! What are you doing here?

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: I came to see you. How you feel?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I gotta pain in my left side, and my leg throbs like a drum.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: I been getting a pain in my shoulder.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I gotta pains in my shoulder too. I have a pain in my hip, and my right arm aches so much I can't sleep. It's a curse to be old. How you feel?

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: I feel fine.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: That's nice.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: We gotta postcard from my son Nickie and his bride. They're inna big hotel in Florida on their honeymoon. Everything is very nice.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: That's nice. I gotta letter from my husband's cousin in Abruzzi. His mother died.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Do you remember Emilio DiGiorgio, owned the tavern in Abruzzi?

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: I don't think I remember him.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Well, he died. You know who else died?

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: You know the old man upstairs in this house. Old Irishman, always drunk. He got pleurisy. He was inna hospital two weeks. He died yesterday.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Well, I always like to visit you, Catherine, because you always got such cheerful news.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I wake up this morning, I hear the baby crying. So I wake up. I come in their room. That girl is shaking her hand atta baby. I said, "You brute! Don't you strike that baby! That's my son's baby!"

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: It's her baby too, you know.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: That's my son Thomas's baby.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Well, it ain't your baby.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Did I tell you she threw the bottle- a milk at me?

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: You told me.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: She's a witch, that one. I tell you what happen yesterday?

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: What happen?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: She gave me the evil eye.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Ufa!

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I keep one eye open when I sleep, because she's gonna come in, stab me in my bed.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Catherine, I want you come live in my house with Marty and me.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Ah?

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: You son Thomas and Virginia, they come to my house this afternoon...

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Your son Thomas and his wife Virginia...

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: When was this?

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: This afternoon, about four, five o'clock.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: What they say?

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: You know what they say. They say things are no good in this house. Catherine, your son is married. Leave him in peace. He wantsa be alone with his wife. They don't want no old lady sitting inna balcony. Now I tell you what I think. I want you come live with me in my house with Marty and me. In my house, you have your own room. You don't have to sleep onna couch inna living room like here. We will cook inna kitchen and talk like when we were girls. You are dear to me, and you are dear to Marty. We are pleased for you to come.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: My son Thomas came to see you this afternoon, and he said to you he wants to cast his mother from his house?

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Catherine, don't make an opera outta this. The three-a you anna baby live in three skinny rooms. You are an old goat, and she has an Italian temper. She is a good girl, but you drive her crazy. Catherine, you are no fool. You know this is no good, an old woman living with a husband and wife. Two women inna same kitchen, anna house burns down.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: So I am an old garbage bag, put inna street.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Oh, Catherine, please! Don't make a tragedy. You come to my house where you know you be happier yourself.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: It pains that they should do this.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: I know it pains.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Catherine, you are very dear to me. We have cried many times together. When my husband died, I would have gone insane if it were not for you. I ask you to come to my house, because I can make you happy. Please come to my house.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: These are the worst years. I tell you. It's gonna happen to you. I'm afraida look inna mirror. I'm afraid I'm gonna see an old lady with white hair, like the old ladies inna park, little bundles inna black shawl, waiting for the coffin. I'm fifty- six years old. What am I to do with myself? I have strength in my hands. I wanna cook. I wanna clean. I wanna make dinner for my children. Am I an old dog to lie in fronta the fire til my eyes close? These are the terrible years, Theresa! Terrible years!

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Catherine, my sister...

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Hey, I come home from your house last night, Marty was here with a girl.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Marty.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Your son Marty?

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Well, what Marty you think is gonna be here in this house with a girl?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Were the lights on?

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Oh sure.  This girl is a college graduate.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: They're the worst. College girls are one step from the streets. They smoke like men inna saloon. My son Joseph, his wife, you know, she types onna typewriter. One step from the streets, I tell you. Mrs. Pilletti ponders this philosophy for a moment.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: That's the first time Marty ever brought a girl to this house. She seems like a nice girl. I think he has a feeling for this girl. You heard him sing. He been singing like that all morning.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Well, that's all. You will see. Today, tomorrow, inna week, he's gonna say to you, "Hey, Ma, it's no good being a single man. I'm tired-a running around." Then he's gonna say, "Hey, Ma, wadda we need this old house? Why don't we sell this old house, move into a nicer parta town? A nice little apartment?"

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: I don't sell this house, I tell you that. This is my husband's house. I had six children in this house.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: You will see. A coupla months, you gonna be an old lady, sleeping onna couch in her daughter-in-law's house.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Catherine, you are a blanket of gloom. Wherever you are, the rain follows. Someday, you gonna smile, and we gonna declare a holiday.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: You come up here often?

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: I was up here twice before. Once with a friend of mine and once I came up alone. The last time... do you see that girl in the gray dress sitting over there?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: Well, the last time I was up here, that's where I sat. I sat there for an hour and a half, without moving a muscle. Now and then, some fellow would sort of walk up to me and then change his mind. I'll never forget just sitting there for an hour and a half with my hands in my lap. Then I began to cry, and I had to get up and go home.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I cry a lot too. I'm a big cryer.

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: This is something recent with me, this bursting into tears at the least thing.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Oh, I cry all the time, any little thing. My brothers, my brother-in- laws, they're always telling me what a goodhearted guy I am. Well, you don't get goodhearted by accident. You get kicked around long enough, you get to be a real professor of pain. I know exactly how you feel. And I also want you to know I'm having a very good time with you now and really enjoying myself. So you see, you're not such a dog as you think you are.

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: I'm having a very good time, too.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: So there you are. So I guess I'm not such a dog as I think I am.

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: You're a very nice guy, and I don't know why some girl hasn't grabbed you off long ago.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I don't know either. I think I'm a very nice guy. I also think I'm a pretty smart guy in my own way.

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: I'm twenty-nine years old. How old are you?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I'm thirty-four.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: ...you teach chemistry? That's funny. Where? What school?

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: Benjamin Franklin High School.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Benjamin Franklin, where's that? Brooklyn? I went to Theodore Roosevelt right up here on Fordham Road. It's right arounna corner from my house. I have a cousin who's a teacher. He teaches Latin. He lives in Chicago. He was studying to be a Jesuit, but he gave it up after his first vows.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: You gotta real nice face, you know? It's really a nice face.

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: ...When I got outta the army, Clara, I was lost. I didn't know what I wanted to do. I was twenny-five years old, what was I gonna do, go back to my old job, forty cents an hour. I thought maybe I go to college under the G.I. Biller Rights, you know? But I wouldn't graduate till I was twenny-eight, twenny-nine years old, even if I made it in three years. And my brother Freddie wanted to get married, and I had three unmarried sisters -- in an Italian home, that's a terrible thing. And my kid brother Nickie, he's a one got married last week. So I just went to pieces. I used to walk inna streets till three, four o'clock inna mornings. My mother used to be so worried about me. My uncle Mario come over one time. He offered me a job driving his hack onna night shift. He got his own cab, you know. And God forgive me for what I'm gonna say now, but I used to thinka doing away with myself. I used to stand sometimes in the subway, and God forgive me what I'm going to say, I used to feel the tracks sucking me down under the wheels.

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: Yes, I know.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I'm a Catholic, you know, and even to think about suicide is a terrible sin.

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: Yes, I know.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: So then Mr. Gazzara -- he was a frienda my father -- he offered me this job in his butcher shop, and everybody pleaded with me to take it. So that's what happened. I didn't wanna be a butcher.

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: There's nothing wrong with being a butcher.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Well, I wouldn't call it an elegant profession. It's in a lower social scale. People look down on butchers.

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: I don't.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Well, the point is Mr. Gazzara wantsa sell his shop now, because he and his wife are lonely, and they wanna move out to California in Los Angeles and live near their married daughter. Because she's always writing them to come out there. So it's a nice little shop. I handle his books for him, so I know he has a thirty-five percent markup which is not unreasonable, and he takes home net maybe a hundred, hundred and fifty bucks a week. The point is, of course, you gotta worry about the supermarkets. There's two inna neighborhood now, and there's an A&P coming in, at least that's the rumor. Of course, mosta his trade is strictly Italian, but the younger Italian girls, they get married, and they don't stick to the old Italian dishes so much. I mean, you gotta take that into account too.

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: It's my feeling that you really want to buy this shop, Marty.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: That's true. I do. But I'm gonna have to take outta loan inna bank eight thousand dollars. That's a big note to carry, because I have to give Mr. Gazzara a mortgage, and what I have to weigh is: will it pay off in the end more than I can make onna salary?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Wadda you think?

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: I think anything you want to do, you'll do well.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I only got about three bucks on me now, but I just live about eight blocks from here on the other side of Webster Avenue. Why don't we walk back to my house? I'll run in, pick up some dough, and let's step out somewhere.

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: I really should get home...

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: It's only a quarter of twelve. The clock's right over there.

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: I really should get home, I told my father... Well, I suppose a little while longer. I wonder if there's any place around here I could put some makeup on...

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: ...It's really a fine opportunity for me. But I'm not sure I want to be a department head. It's mostly executive and administrative work. Well, anyway, I told you about my father, and he depends on me a great deal, and...

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Why don't you just move out to Portchester?

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: Well, that's what I was saying. My father is getting old. And we're very close. He's a wonderful man, really...

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I think you're kidding yourself, Clara. I used to think about moving out, you know? And that's what I used to say. "My mother needs me." But when you really get down to it, that ain't it at all. Actually, you need your father. You know what I mean? You're living at home, and you got your father and mother there, and you can go on like that -- being a little girl all your life.

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: I'm afraid of being lonely.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Oh, you won't be so lonely. You'll make friends right away.

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: Actually, I don't make friends easily.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: What're you talking about? You're a real likeable person. You'll make friends out there in Portchester one, two, three. You'll have people visiting you alla time. I'll come visit you. I'll borrow my brother Freddie's car, or you can call me up when you feel blue, or I'll call you up. And it's gonna be nice. Don't be so afraid.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: This is the kitchen.

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: Yes, I know.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Come on inna dining room.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Siddown, take off your coat. You want something to eat? We gotta whole half-chicken in the icebox.

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: No, thank you. I don't think I should stay very long.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Sure. Just take off your coat a minute.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: So I was telling you, my kid brother Nickie got married last Sunday. That was a very nice affair. And they had this statue of some woman, and they had whiskey spouting outta her mouth. I never saw anything so grand in my life.  And watta meal. I'm a butcher, so I know a good hunka steak when I see one. That was choice filet, right off the toppa the chuck. A buck eighty a pound. Of course, if you wanna cheaper cut, get rib steak. That gotta lotta waste on it, but it comes to about a buck and a quarter a pound, if it's trimmed. Listen, Clara, make yourself comfortable. You're all tense.

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: Oh, I'm fine.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: You want me to take you home, I'll take you home.

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: Maybe that would be a good idea.

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: No, Marty, please...

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I like you. I like you. I been telling you all night, I like you...

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: Marty...

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I just wanna kiss, that's all.

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: No...

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Please...

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: No...

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Please...

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: Marty...

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Waddaya doing tomorrow night?

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I'll call you up tomorrow morning. Maybe, we'll go see a movie.

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: I'd like that very much.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: The reason I can't be definite about it now is my Aunt Catherine is probably coming over tomorrow, and I may have to help out.

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: I'll wait for your call.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: We better get started to your house, because the buses only run about one an hour now.

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: All right.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Waddaya doing New Year's Eve?

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: What happened, Angie, was that we thought we were just gonna go for a short walk, and then we thought we were gonna come right back, but we got to talking. Listen, Angie, I want you to meet Clara...  Clara, this is my best friend, Angie. I told you about him.

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: How do you do?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: You got an elevator in this house?

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: We just live one flight up.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: So I'll call you tomorrow.

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Okay, so I'll see you tomorrow night then.

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Siddown, siddown. You want some chicken? We got some chicken in the ice box.

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: No, Mrs. Pilletti. We were just going home. Thank you very much anyway.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Well, siddown a minute. I just come inna house. I'll take off my coat. Siddown a minute.

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: No, thank you, really, Mrs. Pilletti.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: It's a very sad business, I tell you. A woman, fifty-six years old, all her life, she had her own home. Now she's just an old lady, sleeping on her daughter-in-law's couch. It's a curse to be a mother, I tell you. Your children grow up and then what is left for you to do? What is a mother's life but her children? It is a very cruel thing when your son has no place for you in his home.

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: Couldn't she find some sort of hobby to fill out her time?

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Hobby! What can she do? She cooks and she cleans. You gotta have a house to clean. You gotta have children to cook for. These are the terrible years for a woman, the terrible years.

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: You mustn't feel too harshly against her daughter-in-law. She also wants to have a house to clean and a family to cook for.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: You don't think my sister Catherine should live in her daughter-in-law's house?

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: Well, I don't know the people, of course, but as a rule, I don't think a mother-in-law should live with a young couple.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Where do you think a mother-in-law should go?

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: I don't think a mother should depend so much upon her children for her rewards in life.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Well, maybe that's what they teach you in New York University. In real life, it don't work out that way. You wait till you are a mother.

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: It's silly of me to argue about it. I don't know the people involved.

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: It was very nice meeting you, Mrs. Pilletti. I hope I'll see you again.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: CLARA
turns.text: Goodnight, Mrs. Pilletti.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Goodnight.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: You say something?

turns.speaker: DR. KEEGAN
turns.text: Yeah. I was just asking you if you was here stag or with a girl.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I'm stag.

turns.speaker: DR. KEEGAN
turns.text: Well, I'll tell you. I got stuck on a blind date with a dog, and I just met an old girl I used to know, and I was wondering how I'm gonna get rid of the girl I'm with. Somebody to take her home, you know what I mean? I'd be glad to pay you five bucks if you take her home for me.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: DR. KEEGAN
turns.text: I'll take you over, and I'll introduce you as an old army buddy of mine, and then I'll cut out. Because I got this other girl waiting for me out by the hatcheck, and I'll pay you five bucks.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Are you kidding?

turns.speaker: DR. KEEGAN
turns.text: No, I'm not kidding.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: You can't just walk off onna girl like that.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Herbie! Wadda you doing here?!

turns.speaker: DR. KEEGAN
turns.text: I came up to dance, wadda you think? You here with somebody?

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: I'm just here with another girl.

turns.speaker: DR. KEEGAN
turns.text: Where you going now?

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: I'm just gonna get my cigarettes. I left them in my coat.

turns.speaker: DR. KEEGAN
turns.text: I'll see you around.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: I'll see you.

turns.speaker: SECOND IRISH WOMAN
turns.text: She was always a bit thin in the hips...

turns.speaker: FIRST IRISH WOMAN
turns.text: Well, at the time she told me this, she already had six. Every time I saw the woman, she was either...

turns.speaker: SECOND IRISH WOMAN
turns.text: And that husband of hers is a skinny bit of a fellow, isn't he?

turns.speaker: FIRST IRISH WOMAN
turns.text: Well, I bumped into her on the street, and she was as big as a barrel.

turns.speaker: SECOND IRISH WOMAN
turns.text: Oh, that's nice. So the doctor was wrong, wasn't he?

turns.speaker: FIRST IRISH WOMAN
turns.text: Oh, no! She died right in the hospital...

turns.speaker: SECOND IRISH WOMAN
turns.text: Oh, that's a sad story. And her husband is that little fellow, works in Peter Reeves.

turns.speaker: FIRST IRISH WOMAN
turns.text: That's the one.

turns.speaker: SECOND IRISH WOMAN
turns.text: Oh, that's a sad story.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: ...so the whole book winds up, Mike Hammer, he's inna room there with this doll. So he says, "You rat, you are the murderer." So she begins to con him, you know? She tells him how she loves him. And then Bam! He shoots her in the stomach. So she's laying there, gasping for breath, and she says, "How could you do that?" And he says, "It was easy."

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: Boy, that Mickey Spillane, boy he can write.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: What I like about Mickey Spillane is he knows how to handle women. In one book, he picks up a tomato who gets hit with a car, and she throws a pass at him. And then he meets two beautiful twins, and they throw passes at him. And then he meets some beautiful society leader, and she throws a pass at him, and...

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: Boy, that Mickey Spillane, he sure can write.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I always figure a guy oughta marry a girl who's twenny years younger than he is so that when he's forty, his wife is a real nice-looking doll.

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: That means he'd have to marry the girl when she was one year old.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I never thoughta that.

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: What time is it?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: About eight o'clock.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Tommy, before you go, I wonder if you gimme a little advice.

turns.speaker: THOMAS
turns.text: Sure, what?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: You're the accountant inna family, and I figure you might know about these things. My boss wantsa sell his shop to me. His kids are all married, you know, and he and his wife live alone, and they wanna move out to California where his daughter lives, so he wantsa sell his shop. He wants five thousand dollars down, although I think I can knock him downa four...

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: All right, I'll see you, Thomas, because he wants an answer by Monday.

turns.speaker: THOMAS
turns.text: Sure. Thanks a lot about my mother. We'll work out some arrangement, because naturally I want to pay...

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Don't worry about it.

turns.speaker: THOMAS
turns.text: No, listen, that's my mother, I'm gonna pay for her...

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Boy, beautiful day, hey, Thomas?

turns.speaker: THOMAS
turns.text: Sure, great if you ain't married.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Tommy, gimme a coupla minutes, because I promised Mr. Gazzara I'd let him know tomorrow. See, what I wanna know, Tom, if a buncha individual retail merchants get together, how does it operate? On individual mark- ups? You know what I mean? Say I'm the butcher and Aldo Capelli, he's the dairyman and grocer, so suppose I mark up thirty-five percent, but he works on forty, so...

turns.speaker: THOMAS
turns.text: Waddaya talking about, do you know what you're talking about?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: No, I don't know. That's why I'm asking you.

turns.speaker: THOMAS
turns.text: Wadda you wanna buy a shop for, will you tell me? You gotta good job, you got no wife, you got no responsibilities. Boy, I wish I was you, boy. Waddaya wanna tie yourself down with a shop? What's he want? Five thousand down? You're gonna have to carry a mortgage sixty, seventy bucks a month. A mortgage anna note from the bank. For Pete's sake, you're a single man with no responsibilities. Stay that way, boy. Take my advice.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Well, you see, Thomas I figure the big problem is the supermarkets. But Patsy's shop, that's a specialized trade. The supermarkets don't carry Italian meat.

turns.speaker: THOMAS
turns.text: Who buys Italian meat anymore? You think my wife buys Italian meat?  She goes to the A&P, picks up some lamb chops wrapped in cellophane, opens up a canna peas, and that's dinner, boy.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Well, I understand the problem about the supermarkets, but I was talking to this girl last night, and she made the point that a likeable personality is a valuable business asset.

turns.speaker: THOMAS
turns.text: Marty, see that my mother is nice and comfortable, eh?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Sure. This girl said...

turns.speaker: THOMAS
turns.text: What girl, what does she know?  Why don't you let her hold the baby once in a while?! Your mother, boy, she wantsa take the kid for a day, that's fine!

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Hello, Marty, when you coming home? Where you now? Because your cousin Thomas and his wife Virginia, they're here. They had another fight with your Aunt Catherine... I don't know...

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I'm coming home right now, Ma. I'll be home in about two minutes. Tell Thomas stick around, I wanna see him about something.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Hello, Ma.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Marty, Thomas and Virginia are here. They had another fight with your Aunt Catherine. So they ask me, would it be all right if Catherine come to live with us. So I said, all right with me, but we have to ask you. Marty, she's a lonely old lady. Nobody wants her. Everybody's throwing her outta their house...

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Sure, Ma, it's okay with me.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: You gotta good heart.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Oh, we got plenny-a room here.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Sure! Sure! It's gonna be nice! It's gonna be nice! I'll come over tonight to your house, and I talk with Catherine, and you see, everything is gonna work out all right.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: So what are you gonna do tonight, Marty?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I don't know, Ma. I'm all knocked out. I may just hang arounna house.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: I say, why don't you go to the Stardust Ballroom? It's loaded with tomatoes.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: It's loaded with what?

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Tomatoes.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Ha! Who told you about the Stardust Ballroom?

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Thomas. He told me it was a very nice place.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Oh, Thomas. Ma, it's just a big dance hall, and that's all it is. I been there a hundred times. Loaded with tomatoes. Boy, you're funny, Ma.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Marty, I don't want you hang arounna house tonight. I want you to go take a shave and go out and dance.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Ma, when are you gonna give up? You gotta bachelor on your hands. I ain't never gonna get married.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: You gonna get married.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Sooner or later, there comes a point in a man's life when he gotta face some facts, and one fact I gotta face is that whatever it is that women like, I ain't got it. I chased enough girls in my life. I went to enough dances. I got hurt enough. I don't wanna get hurt no more. I just called a girl just now, and I got a real brush-off, boy. I figured I was past the point of being hurt, but that hurt. Some stupid woman who I didn't even wanna call up. She gave me the brush. I don't wanna go to the Stardust Ballroom because all that ever happened to me there was girls made me feel like I was a bug. I got feelings, you know. I had enough pain. No, thank you.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Marty...

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Ma, I'm gonna stay home and watch Jackie Gleason.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: You gonna die without a son.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: So I'll die without a son.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Put on your blue suit...

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Blue suit, gray suit, I'm still a fat man. A fat ugly man.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: You not ugly.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I'm ugly... I'm ugly! I'm UGLY!

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Marty...

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Ma! Leave me alone!

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Hello, Marty, when you come home?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: We just got here about fifteen minutes ago. Ma, I want you to meet Miss Clara Snyder. She's graduate of New York University. She teaches chemistry in Benjamin Franklin High School.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: How'd you come home, Ma? Thomas give you a ride?

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Oh, it's a sad business.  My sister, Catherine, she don't get along with her daughter-in-law, so she's gonna come live with us.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Oh, she's coming, eh, Ma?

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Oh, sure.  Siddown, siddown. Marty, tell her siddown.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Might as well siddown a minute, Clara.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Did you offer the young lady some fruit?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I offered her, Ma, she don't want nothing.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Ma, I'm gonna take her home now. It's getting late, and the buses only run about one an hour.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: All right, Ma. I'll be back in about an hour, an hour anna half.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Hello, Ma, waddaya say, it's getting a little late.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: That was a nice girl last night, Marty.  She wasn't a very good-looking girl, but she looks like a nice girl.  I said, she wasn't a very good-looking girl... not very pretty...

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I heard you, Ma.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: She looks a little old for you. About thirty-five, forty years old?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: She's twenty-nine, Ma.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: She's more than twenty-nine years old, Marty. That's what she tells you.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: What, Ma?

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: She looks thirty-five, forty. She didn't look Italian to me.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: I said, is she Italian girl?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I don't know. I don't think so.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: What are you talking about? She's a nice girl.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: She didn't look Italian to me.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: I don't like her.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: You don't like her. You only met her for two minutes.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Don't bring her to the house no more.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: What didn't you like about her?

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: I don't know! She don't look like Italian to me. Plenny a nice Italian girls around.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Well, let's not get inna fight about it, Ma.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: So what are you gonna do tonight, Marty?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I don't know, Ma. I'm all knocked out. I think I'll just hang arounna house and watch...

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: So these two girls come over to the bar...

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Hey, Ang'...

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: ...and they sit down right next to me...

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: You want a beer, Ang'?

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: I look over at this one nexta me, not bad, about thirty-five -- Hiya, Marty...

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Hiya, Ralph...

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: ...I been talking about two nurses Leo and me picked up in a bar on Seventy-First Street.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Hey, Lou, gimme two bottles-a beer...

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: So, Marty, lemme tell you about these nurses, Marty...

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Waddaya read there, Joe?

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: So, Marty, let me tell you about these nurses...

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: What nurses?

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: The nurses Leo and me picked up last night. We got a date with them tonight.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: You still owe me ten bucks from last week, if that's what you're working up to.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Hello, Ralph.

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: Hey, Marty, come over here a minute.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Waddaya mean, Ralph?

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: Hey, Louise, I want you to meet Marty Pilletti. Marty, that's Louise Kelly, inna back seat there.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Hiya.
